## Percentage of women MPs

```{r}
library(rvest)
library(dplyr)
library(ggplot2)
library(tidyr)
library(tidyverse)
library(lubridate)

url <- "https://de.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frauenanteil_im_Deutschen_Bundestag_seit_1949"

webpage <- read_html(url)

## get all tables on the page
tables <- html_nodes(webpage, "table")

# second table on the page
table_2 <- tables[[2]] %>%
  html_table(fill = TRUE)

colnames(table_2) <- make.names(colnames(table_2), unique = TRUE)

table_2_cleaned <- table_2 %>%
  filter(str_detect(Wahlperiode, "Bundestag")) %>%
  mutate(Year = as.numeric(str_extract(Wahlperiode, "\\d{4}"))) %>%
  select(Year, everything())

colnames(table_2_cleaned) <- c("Year", "Wahlperiode", "CDU.CSU_per", 
                               "CDU.CSU_seats", "FDP_per", "FDP_seats", 
                               "SPD_per", "SPD_seats", "Gruene_per", 
                               "Gruene_seats", "Linke_per", "Linke_seats", 
                               "AfD_per", "AfD_seats")

# table_2_cleaned$CDU.CSU_per <- gsub(",", ".", table_2_cleaned$CDU.CSU_per)
# table_2_cleaned$CDU.CSU_per <- gsub("%", "", table_2_cleaned$CDU.CSU_per)
# table_2_cleaned$CDU.CSU_per <- gsub("[^0-9\\.]", "", table_2_cleaned$CDU.CSU_per)
# table_2_cleaned$CDU.CSU_per <- as.numeric(trimws(table_2_cleaned$CDU.CSU_per))

clean_per_column <- function(x) {
  x <- gsub(",", ".", x) 
  x <- gsub("%", "", x) 
  x <- gsub("[^0-9\\.]", "", x) 
  x <- as.numeric(trimws(x)) 
  return(x)
}

## get all columns ending with '_per'
per_columns <- grep("_per$", names(table_2_cleaned), value = TRUE)

table_2_cleaned[per_columns] <- lapply(table_2_cleaned[per_columns], clean_per_column)

table_2_long <- table_2_cleaned %>%
  pivot_longer(cols = c(CDU.CSU_per, FDP_per, SPD_per, Gruene_per, Linke_per, AfD_per),
               names_to = "party", values_to = "percentage_women") %>%
  mutate(
    # Clean percentage data
    percentage_women = as.numeric(gsub(",", ".", gsub("%", "", percentage_women))),
    party = gsub("_per", "", party)  # Clean the party names
  )

ggplot(table_2_long, aes(x=Year, y=percentage_women, color=party, group=party)) +
  geom_step(size=2) + 
  # geom_point(size=2) +
  scale_y_continuous(limits=c(0, 100), labels=scales::percent_format(scale=1)) +
  scale_color_manual(values=c(
    "AfD"="#009EE0", 
    "CDU.CSU"="black",
    "FDP"="goldenrod", #FFED00
    "Gruene"="#64A12D",
    "Linke"="#BE3075",
    "SPD"="#EB001F"
  )) +
  labs(title="Proportion of Women in Bundestag by Party", x="",
    y="Percentage of Women", color="Party") +
  theme_minimal() + 
  theme(text=element_text(family="sans", size=18), 
        plot.title=element_text(hjust=0.5))

```


## Oldest/youngest MPs

```{r}

  ErstJahr = c(1990, 1994, 1998, 2002, 2005, 2009, 2013, 2017, 2021, 2025),
  SPD = c(48.8, 49.9, 50.4, 50.7, 50.3, 51.7, 50.1, 50.5, 46.2, 48),
  CDU.CSU = c(49.0, 49.4, 50.9, 48.5, 49.8, 49.5, 49.9, 50, 49.2, 48.3),
  Gruene = c(41.3, 41.7, 43.3, 45, 46.3, 46.7, 46.4, 47, 42.5, 42.3),
  FDP = c(48.9, 51.6, 50.9, 50.6, 47.7, 47.6, NA, 45.5, 47.7, NA),
  Linke = c(43.3, 48.5, 47, NA, 48.5, 48.6, 50.7, 50, 50.3, 42.2),
  AfD = c(NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, 42, 37, 50.7)
)

df_long <- df %>%
  pivot_longer(cols = c(SPD, CDU.CSU, Gruene, FDP, Linke, AfD),
               names_to = "Partei", values_to = "Alter")

# ggplot(df_long, aes(x = as.factor(ErstJahr), y = Alter, fill = Partei)) +

ggplot(df_long, aes(x = as.factor(ErstJahr), y = Alter, color = Partei, group = Partei)) +

        "AfD" = "#009EE0",
```

## Percentage of MPs with migration background

```{r}
## https://www1.wdr.de/nachrichten/bundestagswahl-2025/bundestag-zusammensetzung-statistik-100.html
## https://mediendienst-integration.de/artikel/mehr-abgeordnete-mit-migrationshintergrund-1.html
## https://mediendienst-integration.de/artikel/abgeordnete-mit-migrationshintergrund.html
## https://mediendienst-integration.de/artikel/mehr-abgeordnete-mit-migrationshintergrund.html

df_mig <- data.frame(
  Wahlperiode = c("17. WP","18. WP","19. WP", "20. WP", "21. WP"),
  ErstJahr = c(2009, 2013, 2017, 2021, 2025),
  SPD = c(2.7, 6.7, 9.8, 17, 17.5),
  CDU.CSU = c(0.4, 2.9, 2.9, 4.1, 6.3),
  Gruene = c(7.9, 11.1, 14.9, 14.4, 20),
  FDP = c(NA, NA, 6.3, 5.4, NA),
  Linke = c(8.8, 12.5, 18.8, 28.2, 18.8),
  AfD = c(NA, NA, 8.7, 7.2, 5.9)
)

df_mig_long <- df_mig %>%
  pivot_longer(cols = c(SPD, CDU.CSU, Gruene, FDP, Linke, AfD), 
               names_to = "Partei", 
               values_to = "Percentage")

ggplot(df_mig_long, aes(x = as.factor(ErstJahr), y = Percentage, fill = Partei)) +
  geom_bar(stat = "identity", position = position_dodge()) +
  scale_y_continuous("", limits=c(0, NA), labels=scales::percent_format(scale=1))+
  # scale_y_continuous(limits = c(0, NA)) +
  scale_fill_manual(values=c(
    "AfD"="#009EE0",
    "CDU.CSU"="black",
    "FDP"="goldenrod", #FFED00
    "Gruene"="#64A12D",
    "Linke"="#BE3075",
    "SPD"="#EB001F"
```

## Refresher on party membership concepts

- [party activists or members tend to hold more radical views than the average party voter]{style="color:blue;"}
    + [median voter theorem]{style="color:red;"}: parties should converge toward the centre to win elections, but...
    + activists/members: typically more committed and engaged; typically have stronger ideological
        * impact through party primaries and internal decision-making

. . . 

- [descriptive representation]{style="color:red;"}: *extent to which elected officials resemble the demographic characteristics of constituents* <!-- (e.g., race, gender, ethnicity) -->
- [substantive representation]{style="color:red;"}: *degree to which elected officials advocate and act for their constituents' needs, preferences, or policy concerns, regardless of shared demographic traits*

## Variation among far-right parties

- Common traits
    + predominantly male activist/member bases 
    + typically less (but not 'no') ethnic/racial diversity in membership and representation

<!-- + members' connections to other social organisations  -->

. . . 

- Notable divergences
    + differences of party membership size 
        * e.g., Dutch PVV, 1 member (Wilders); Indian BJP, 170 million
    + internal party differences
        * loosely constrained (*personalist parties*): centralised, leader dominates 
        * highly constrained: party rules, intra-party competition

## Factionalism within far-right parties

- frequent divisions between national and regional/local level representatives
- open question of whether [local representatives more radical or more pragmatic]{style="color:red;"}

## @WeeksETAL2022

RQ: *Under what conditions do we see an increase in RRP parties' women MPs? Given that RRP parties have traditionally held very conservative views on the role of women in society, what accounts for this increase in women’s representation?*

## @WeeksETAL2022 

|      | *LOW M/F voter ratio* | *HIGH M/F voter ratio*  |
|------|-----------------------|-------------------------|
| *LOW electoral threat*  | *Status quo*: Party does well among men and women, and at the polls. No need to include more women in party. | *Strategic Exclusion (H1b)*: Party with a men-dominated electorate that gains votes doubles down on exclusion of women in the party. |
| *HIGH electoral threat* | *Status quo*: Party already attracts women voters, so will not target women voters as a strategy to improve vote share | *Strategic Inclusion (H1a)*: Party with a men-dominated electorate that loses votes elects women to appeal to untapped women voters. |

## Reading a regression table

<!-- http://svmiller.com/blog/2014/08/reading-a-regression-table-a-guide-for-students/ -->

Remember: regression is a tool for understanding a phenomenon as a linear function (generally) &rarr; (y = mx + b)

1. Numbers not in parentheses next to a variable: __regression coefficient__: expected change in DV for a one-unit increase in IV. NB: ositive or negative relationship?

2. Numbers inside parentheses next to a variable: __standard error__: estimate of the standard deviation of the coefficient

3. Asterisks/'stars': __statistical significance__: probability of results as extreme as observed result, under the assumption that the null hypothesis is correct. Smaller p-value means such an observation would be less likely under null hypothesis; hence, significance. Statistical significance suggests more precise estimates---NOT necessarily that one IV is more important than another.

## Reply [@weeks2024ResponseRadicalRightParties]

- @guinaudeau2024RadicalRightPartiesUse misunderstand treatment of outliers
- should not 'arbitrarily delete one influential case but not another'
    + "When *all* influential cases are removed, and not just the observation of FN in 2012, our key findings do not change."

> Deleting correctly-coded higher influence observations makes the sample an inaccurate representation of the population, and thus can lead to improper inferences about a population, particularly in a small population like the data on radical right populist parties in Europe.
